source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Irradiation growth of recrystallized annealed (RXA) Zircaloy is divided into four stages

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Stage I is a shorttime, low-strain transient caused by the accumulation of point defects, small interstitial loops, and vacancy clusters

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Stage II is a quasi-steady-state region of relatively low strain rate during which the loops grow and intrinsic dislocations climb

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Stage III is a transient during which the strain rate increases due to the production and motion of irradiation-induced dislocation lines

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Stage IV is a high-strain-rate, steady-state region during which nonrecoverable strain is caused predominantly by glide of the irradiationinduced dislocations

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Observed density decreases are less than 0.1%

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: positive strains as high as 1.1% have been reported in specimens irradiated by fast neutrons at high temperature and flux

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: specimens of an alloy of 5 to 7 weight % plutonium in alpha zirconium grew to approximately 2 to 4 times their original lengths after burnups to 0.8 to 1.8% with density changes of less than 3%
composition_raw: 5 to 7 weight % plutonium in alpha zirconium

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: density changes of less than 3%
composition_raw: 5 to 7 weight % plutonium in alpha zirconium

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Zircaloy growth behavior at ~550 K and ~10^18 neutrons m^-2·s^-1 (E > 1 MeV) for longitudinally oriented material

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Stage I is a short-time, low-strain (< ~0.1%) transient in which the strain rate, initially high, continuously decreases

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: The strain rate in this region increases with increasing cold work and reaches a maximum value approximately equal to that for Stage IV growth

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Stage IV is a steady-state region in which the strain rate is approximately the same for either RXA or SRA Zircaloy

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Schematic illustrating four stages ofirradiation growth of Zircaloy at ${ \sim } 5 5 0 K$ and $I { \boldsymbol { 0 } } ^ { 1 8 }$ $\pmb { n } \cdot \pmb { m } ^ { - 2 } \cdot \pmb { s } ^ { - 1 }$ $[ \mathbf { E } > I \ M e V $ . Roman numeral stages are for RXA material.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Adamson et al [2] suggested the existence of Stage III based on elongation results from pressurized-water reactor (PWR) fuel guide assemblies reported by Melehan.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Stages II, III, and IV growth are evident in the curve shown in Fig. 1 for alpha uranium.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: Burgers vectors of stable dislocations in_hexagonal close-packed metals are, from theoretical considerations, $^ 1 / _ { 2 }$ (1120), (0001), and $^ 1 / _ { 3 }$ (1123), the latter being of marginal stability

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: Woo et al [23] have observed $\langle c \rangle$ -component Burgers vectors near deformation twins and grain boundary junctions in unirradiated Zircaloy

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: displacement spike consists of an unstable cylindrical void of, perhaps, $3 \mathrm { n m }$ diameter by about $1 5 \mathrm { n m }$ long

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: in perhaps one out of a thousand events an interstitial loop is formed $_ { \cdot \sim 1 }$ to $^ { 5 \mathfrak { n } }$ in diameter

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: vacancy-rich region (Seeger zone) remains in the displacement spike area. These zones are assumed to remain stable at 1 to $^ { 5 \mathfrak { n } }$ in diameter

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: Interstitial loops have a distribution of sizes ranging from ${ \sim } 3$ to $\sim 2 0 \textrm { n }$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: maximum average diameter reached by the zones $( < 5 ~ \mathfrak { n } )$ is much less than that for the loops (approximately $1 5 { \mathfrak { n } }$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: maximum average diameter reached by the zones $( < 5 ~ \mathfrak { n } )$ is much less than that for the loops (approximately $1 5 { \mathfrak { n } }$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk4
evidence_span: When the density and sizes of the loops become sufficiently large that the maximum density of dislocations which the metal can hold has been reached, internal stresses associated with strain fields surrounding the loops reach a critical value.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk4
evidence_span: Loops, intrinsic dislocations, and irradiation-induced dislocations all contribute to macroscopic strain, and this strain is manifested with approximately the same anisotropy.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk4
evidence_span: The motion of the irradiation-induced dislocations relieves the strain in the lattice sufficient to keep the stress at the critical value.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk4
evidence_span: Segments of dislocation loops are also lost to this strain mechanism at a rate which maintains the total dislocation density (due to loops, cold work, and the irradiation source) at approximately the saturation level for the metal.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk4
evidence_span: This is a dynamic equilibrium process in which the net rate at which interstitials enter the loops determines, in part, the strain rate at which growth strain occurs.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk4
evidence_span: Because the irradiation-induced source dislocations effectively reach the surface of the metal, they cannot be removed during annealing. Thus, strain from this mechanism is nonrecoverable.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk4
evidence_span: The loops, on the other hand, can be removed by annealing and the strain can be recovered because they can be dissolved by absorbing excess vacancies existing in the metal when its temperature is raised.

evidence_span: Eq 10 gives $\ell \simeq 3 \times 1 0 ^ { - 8 } \mathrm { m }$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk6
evidence_span: the critical stress is estimated to be approximately $2 9 0 \ \mathrm { M P a }$ at $\$ 50\mathrm { \texttt { K } }$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk6
evidence_span: about twice the yield strength of unirradiated RXA material

evidence_span: Figure 12 illustrates the effect of a temperature change in an irradiation history on predicted strain. For one history, temperature was held constant at $\Im \Im 6 \mathrm { \textrm { K } }$ until $1 5 0 0 0 \mathrm { h }$ , at which time it was raised to 617 K

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk7
evidence_span: The effect of flux on predicted growth strain at $5 5 6 ~ \mathrm { \tt K }$ is presented in Fig. 13, where growth strain is plotted versus fluence for two fluxes

evidence_span: Model calculations of irradiation growth of RXA Zircaloy illustrating the effect of a temperature change in the irradiation history on predicted growth

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk8
evidence_span: Model calculations of irradiation growth of RXA Zircaloy illustrating the effect of flux dependence on growth strain versus fluence plots for longitudinal material at $5 5 6 ~ K$

evidence_span: Model calculations of irradiation growth of Zircaloy. Steady-state calculations of the flux dependence exponent as a function of temperature for RXA and highly cold-worked Zircaloy in Regions II and $I V$ of the growth curve

evidence_span: Model calculations of irradiation growth of Zircaloy. Steady-state calculations of the flux dependence exponent as a function of temperature for RXA and highly cold-worked Zircaloy in Regions II and $I V$ of the growth curve

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk9
evidence_span: Carpenter et al [ l l ] have determined c- and a-axis strain and density changes from measurements on single crystals of zirconium in Stage II growth. Their results yield average ratios of ΔV/V/ε_a ≃ 1.06 and ε_c/ε_a = 0.97

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk9
evidence_span: Carpenter et al [ l l ] have determined c- and a-axis strain and density changes from measurements on single crystals of zirconium in Stage II growth. Their results yield average ratios of ΔV/V/ε_a ≃ 1.06 and ε_c/ε_a = 0.97

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk9
evidence_span: Tucker et al reported that ⟨c⟩-component dislocations, whose line density (approximately 10¹⁴ m⁻²) was approximately 20% of that of ⟨a⟩-type loops and curved dislocations

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_032_chunk9
evidence_span: Tucker et al observed that < 0.05% strain was recovered from specimens whose growth strain was as high as 2.0%

evidence_span: Tucker et al observed that < 0.05% strain was recovered from specimens whose growth strain was as high as 2.0%
